importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was updated on this date, indicating ongoing developments in Senate race fundraising dynamics as of late October 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The fundraising data cited in the article refers to the July–September 2025 period, a critical window for campaign financing ahead of the 2026 Senate elections.

keyTakeAways: Democratic candidates outperformed Republicans in all but one of the five most competitive Senate races during the third quarter of 2025.
In Georgia, Sen. Jon Ossoff raised $12 million, surpassing the combined fundraising of three Republican challengers, and now holds over $21 million in reserves.

In North Carolina, former Governor Roy Cooper raised $10.9 million, significantly outpacing Republican Michael Whatley’s $1.4 million, with Democrats viewing the state as a potential seat gain opportunity due to Sen. Thom Tillis’s retirement.
In Maine, Democrat Graham Platner raised $3.2 million, beating Republican Senator Susan Collins, though the entry of Governor Janet Mills as a candidate has shifted the race dynamics.
In New Hampshire, Rep. Chris Pappas raised $1.8 million, outperforming former Massachusetts Senator Scott Brown, who raised $968,000.
In Michigan, Republican Mike Rogers raised $2.2 million, while Democratic Rep. Haley Stevens led the field with $1.9 million, indicating a competitive field on both sides.
The fundraising advantage of Democrats could be critical in preparing for 2026 midterms, especially in states where progressive voters are turning against Republicans.
Democratic fundraising strength may help them flip Republican-held seats, especially in states like Georgia, North Carolina, and Maine, which have seen shifts in political sentiment.

namedEntities.name: Fredreka Schouten

namedEntities.name: Alex Leeds Matthews

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, providing independent and widely circulated news on political fundraising trends in U.S. Senate races.

namedEntities.name: Jon Ossoff

namedEntities.name: Derek Dooley
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A top Republican challenger in Georgia with backing from Governor Brian Kemp, representing GOP efforts to unseat Jon Ossoff.

namedEntities.name: Mike Collins

namedEntities.name: Buddy Carter
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Another Republican candidate in Georgia’s Senate race, part of a trio whose combined fundraising is less than Ossoff’s.

namedEntities.name: Roy Cooper
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A leading Democratic candidate in North Carolina, raising $10.9 million, positioning Democrats as strong contenders in a state with a retiring Republican senator.

namedEntities.name: Michael Whatley
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Republican nominee in North Carolina with strong backing from President Trump, raising significantly less than Roy Cooper.

namedEntities.name: Susan Collins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A long-standing Republican incumbent in Maine, targeted by Democrats as a key seat to flip, with fundraising outperformed by Graham Platner.

namedEntities.name: Graham Platner
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A first-time Democratic candidate in Maine who raised $3.2 million and is endorsed by Bernie Sanders, showing rising grassroots Democratic strength.

namedEntities.name: Janet Mills
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A high-profile Democratic entry into the Maine Senate race, raising $1 million in just 24 hours, signaling a major shift in the race dynamics.

namedEntities.name: Jordan Wood
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A Democratic candidate in Maine who raised nearly $1.5 million, contributing to the competitive Democratic field.

namedEntities.name: Jeanne Shaheen
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Retiring from office in New Hampshire, creating an open seat that Democratic Rep. Chris Pappas is now competing for.

namedEntities.name: Chris Pappas
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Democratic nominee in New Hampshire’s open Senate seat, outperforming former Massachusetts Senator Scott Brown in fundraising.

namedEntities.name: Scott Brown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A Republican candidate in New Hampshire’s Senate race, who raised $968,000, significantly less than Chris Pappas.

namedEntities.name: Mike Rogers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The leading Republican candidate in Michigan’s open Senate race, raising $2.2 million in Q3 2025.

namedEntities.name: Haley Stevens

namedEntities.name: Mallory McMorrow
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A Democratic candidate in Michigan’s Senate race, close behind Haley Stevens in fundraising.

namedEntities.name: Abdul El Sayed

namedEntities.name: Gary Peters

namedEntities.name: Bernie Sanders

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump

namedEntities.name: Governor Brian Kemp
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Backs Derek Dooley, a Republican candidate in Georgia, showing GOP state-level coordination in Senate race strategy.

namedEntities.name: Thom Tillis
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His retirement created the opening for Democrats to target a Republican-held seat in North Carolina.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Democratic candidates have outperformed Republican counterparts in all but one of the five most competitive Senate races during the third quarter of 2025, with strong fundraising leads in Georgia, North Carolina, Maine, and Michigan. In Georgia, Jon Ossoff raised $12 million, significantly surpassing Republican challengers and holding over $21 million in reserves. In North Carolina, Roy Cooper raised $10.9 million, outpacing Michael Whatley despite national backing. Maine’s race has been disrupted by the entry of Governor Janet Mills, who raised $1 million in 24 hours, challenging incumbent Susan Collins. In New Hampshire, Chris Pappas outperformed Scott Brown in fundraising, and in Michigan, Democrats led with Haley Stevens raising $1.9 million against Republican Mike Rogers’ $2.2 million. These fundraising advantages suggest Democrats are better positioned to flip Republican-held seats in 2026 midterms, especially in swing states where progressive voters are shifting.
title: Democrats outperform Republicans with donors across the top Senate races
